reviewText: I was kind of worried after watching season 4 it wasn't as good as the first 3 seasons. I feared the show had reached it's peak. Season 5 shot that idea down quick,fast,and in a hurry! I am currently working in Iraq (not in the milatary)so I don't get to see them til they come out on DVD. I was disappointed when I saw it was only 1 of 2. But I got the first so late I didn't have too long before to 2nd was out. Back to the review everything you loved about seasons 1-3 is back. The action,drama,and most of all comedy is back and better than ever. You will be glad you didn't give up on the series. A must have for anyone who likes a show.

reviewerName: Michael B. Druxman "A Good Story is a Terribl...
reviewText: I've always felt that RESCUE ME was one of the best written, directed and acted series on television, but the creators faltered during this 5th Season.There are still some truly memorable moments in many of the episodes.  A scene between Andrea Roth and Callie Thorne in the firehouse still brings a smile to my face every time I think about it, as does a sequence with the guys at a supermarket.I think that the problem with this season is that it ran 22 episodes, rather than the usual 13, and the writers/producers did not come up with enough story to fill it.  Thus, the plot moves forward at a snail's pace, and there are too many scenes which are just marking time.The season finale is certainly a cliff-hanger.Hopefully, Season 6 will be better. Michael B. Druxman
Title: N/A

reviewText: Season 5 - Part 2 of Rescue Me ranks right up there with the earlier seasons. Great comedic and dramatic writing and the actors are at their peak in this series. Tommy's past comes back to haunt him and his spiral into alcoholism is directly linked to his actions on the day of September 11 2001. The characters reflections on that day are the most mature pieces ever seen on the show and the writers obviously had a lot of interaction with real survivors to gain those insights. There is more firefighting and action in this series than others, which is great. And the comedy is sharp and insightful. All in all a terrific season.
summary: Season 5 Part 2 is a great watch

reviewText: Too bad they stopped making this show.  We really enjoyed Rescue Me.  We were very sad to see it go away.  I hope they revive this in the future.

reviewText: I used to thoroughly enjoy this show.  It was well written, acted, and conceived.  This season saw an end to all that.  Like most long-running American shows, characters have outlived their usefulness and story arcs have begun to repeat and become tiresome.  Some suggestions:1. Get rid of the wife.  It was a brilliant--and necessary--move in Dexter; follow suit.  The city is filled with women and potential story lines.  Being hung-up on your ex for going on years now is the stuff of "Young and the Restless."2. Cut back on Sheila. She is occasionally good for comic relief, but too often is too much.3. Enough with the AA soapbox.  I realize that addiction is a serious ad worthy topic, but the see-saw is tedious.4. Develop more stories about the firehouse characters.  Avoid stunt casting.  (The Michael J. Fox subplot was pointless and ridiculous and having his character squeeze your package for minutes while you stood there and took it made your character weak, nothing else.) It seems as if most characters are now in search of something to do. Find it for them.5.  Don't wait until "end episodes" to pull out the stops and up the ante.This used to be a great show and could be again, but if you've truly run out of ideas, let the show go.  Maybe four or five years is all it should have been to start with.

reviewerName: Tony Rome "mine is fine as wine and I should ...
reviewText: One of the truest things one can say about Denis Leary and his superb show is that any given episode is better acted, written and directed than 99% of the garbage coming out of Hollywood these days...The show can veer on a dime from hip, macho hilarity to dramatic moments that either make you cringe or burn a whole in your psyche...the sequence during season 2, for example, when Tommy Gavin's son is killed by a drink driver was so distrubing, it kept me up half the night...you could literally feel the despair coming from the screen....Season Five volume two wraps the the show's most recent episodes (the show does not return to the air until Summer 2010)....no doubt these episodes hit some kind of dramatic and comedic peak.The bonus features include a segement in which the cast gather round a restaurant table and answers questions from viewers...Example: "Which character on the show would you most like to play other than your own?"The great John Scurti (Lou) answers: "Tommy Gavin, just to see what it would be like if an ACTOR played the part!"This is great stuff!
Title: N/A
